entry.title: Re: How can I securely manage user logins and permissions...
entry.content:
To securely manage user logins and permissions across SAP and non-SAP systems, the best approach is to centralize identity and access management (IAM) and enforce consistent security policies. Here’s a breakdown:

1. Centralized Identity Management:

  • Use an Identity Provider (IdP) like Azure AD, Okta, or SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) to manage user identities in one place.

  • This allows single sign-on (SSO) across SAP and non-SAP systems, reducing password fatigue and improving security.

2. Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define roles and permissions centrally, and map them to specific tasks rather than individual users.

  • Use tools like SAP GRC (Governance, Risk, and Compliance) for SAP systems and integrate with your IAM solution for non-SAP systems.

3. Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):

  • Enforce MFA for all critical systems to add an extra layer of security beyond passwords.

4. Automated Provisioning and De-Provisioning:

  • Integrate IAM with HR systems or employee lifecycle tools to automatically grant/revoke access when employees join, move, or leave the organization.

  • This reduces the risk of orphaned accounts with lingering permissions.

5. Audit and Monitoring:

  • Regularly audit user permissions and access logs.

  • Implement automated alerts for unusual login activity or privilege escalations.

6. Data and System Segmentation:

  • Limit cross-system access to only what’s necessary (principle of least privilege).

  • Use attribute-based access control (ABAC) for fine-grained permission enforcement where possible.

Summary:
Centralize identity, enforce role-based access, automate provisioning, enable MFA, and monitor continuously. This approach keeps logins secure, simplifies administration, and ensures compliance across SAP and non-SAP systems.

entry.title: Resolving UWL Mixed Content Issues in SAP Enterprise Portal After Switching to HTTPS
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

I’m writing this blog to share the resolution of an issue I recently encountered in my project. I hope this post helps anyone facing a similar challenge.

 

Issue Overview

Working Scenario:

We are using SAP Enterprise Portal (with the HTTP protocol) to fetch work items from an SAP S/4HANA 2023 Rise system. The same approach also works with SAP ECC.

The application was functioning perfectly when both the portal and the backend systems were communicating over HTTP, with the connection established through a system alias in the portal.

 

When the Issue Started

As per SAP Rise security guidelines, direct HTTP access to the S/4HANA system was disabled. Consequently, we switched both our portal and load balancer configurations to use HTTPS to ensure secure communication with the backend.

After implementing HTTPS, we tested the UWL (Universal Worklist) functionality. However, instead of loading the work items, the page appeared blank, and the browser console displayed a mixed content error — this happened because the portal (served via HTTPS) was attempting to load the UWL iView using HTTP.

(Please refer to the attached browser console screenshot for reference.) (Mix Content error in Browser Console for UWL in HTTPS.JPG)

 

Analysis

After reviewing several blogs and SAP Community posts, I found an SAP Knowledge Base Article (KBA) that provided the crucial insight:

SAP KBA: 1927272 - How to configure proxy mapping for external access through reverse proxy server

According to this KBA, we needed to update the ProxyMappings parameter in the NetWeaver Administrator (NWA) of the SAP Enterprise Portal.

 

Resolution

To resolve the issue, we made the following configuration change in the NWA:

  • Previous Value:
    ProxyMappings: <Blank>

  • Updated Value: PFA (Updated Value of ProxyMappings.JPG)
    ProxyMappings: 52000=(Host:waslservices.wasl.ae,Port:443,Scheme:https,Override:true)

After applying this change, we restarted all application servers (one by one) to ensure the new settings took effect.

Once the restart was complete, the ESS application navigation and UWL functionality started working correctly.

 

Conclusion

The issue occurred due to recent browser security updates affecting how mixed content is handled in portal navigation. By adjusting the ProxyMappings parameter as per SAP KBA 1927272, we were able to resolve the problem successfully.

I hope this solution helps others who encounter similar HTTPS-related issues in their SAP environment.

 

Best regards,
Rohit Gera

entry.title: Re: How can I securely manage user logins and permissions...
entry.content: Effectively managing user logins and permissions across both SAP and non-SAP systems requires a centralized identity and access management (IAM) strategy. Implementing Single Sign-On (SSO) and leveraging protocols like SAML or OAuth can streamline authentication, while role-based access control (RBAC) ensures users have appropriate permissions. Integrating SAP’s Identity Management (IDM) with your broader IAM framework can help maintain consistency, enforce security policies, and simplify auditing across heterogeneous systems.

entry.title: Re: How can I securely manage user logins and permissions...
entry.content: Great question, Suheb! Managing user logins and permissions across multiple SAP and non-SAP systems requires a combination of identity management, access control policies, and secure authentication practices. Here are some best practices: 1. Centralize Identity Management Single Sign-On (SSO): Implement SSO using protocols like SAML 2.0, OAuth 2.0, or OpenID Connect so users authenticate once to access multiple systems, including SAP, AWS, Azure, and other cloud services. Identity Providers (IdP): Use a centralized IdP like Azure AD, Okta, or SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) to manage all user credentials, reducing password fatigue and improving security. 2. Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) Define roles based on job function, department, or project and assign permissions accordingly. In SAP, leverage authorization objects and composite roles to control access to transactions, reports, and data. For non-SAP systems, map roles to IAM policies in AWS, Azure RBAC, or Google Cloud IAM. 3. Use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) Require MFA for all sensitive systems. Many IdPs can enforce MFA consistently across SAP and cloud platforms, improving security without adding friction. 4. Automate Provisioning & De-Provisioning Use tools like SAP Identity Management (SAP IDM), Azure AD Connect, or Okta Lifecycle Management to automatically create, update, or deactivate accounts based on HR system data. Automation ensures access is granted only when needed and revoked promptly when employees leave or change roles. 5. Monitor & Audit Access Regularly review user activity and permissions. Enable logging and alerts for critical actions in both SAP and cloud platforms. Tools like SAP GRC Access Control or Cloud Security Posture Management (CSPM) can help detect anomalies. 6. Adopt Zero Trust Principles Verify users and devices for every request, even within the corporate network. Implement least-privilege access, giving users only the permissions they need to perform their tasks.

entry.title: Re: Introduction to SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery service for SAP CPI Cloud Foundry enviro
entry.content:
Hello @theodore_abitbol ,

Thanks for your question! Normally, you consider SAP Cloud Transport Management service as central shared service that allows you to control the delivery towards production across your cloud landscape and use cases. So, recommendation would be to run it centrally, such as on a central subaccount for shared services. Technically, this is not a must, it could also run on any other subaccount. It is recommended to not run it on a development subaccount, as it requires destinations to the corresponding production environments, to which you normally want to restrict access.

For SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery, the recommendation is to run it on a team subaccount, to make sure that the credentials securely stored inside the service are only for team resources (that is, that one team does not get access to the credentials from other teams/scenarios).

For general best practices on where to run SAP BTP services, you could check the Sharing SAP BTP Services | SAP Help Portal section of the SAP BTP Administrator's Guide.

I hope this helps!

Best regards,
Boris

entry.title: Re: Custom field not accessible in /SCWM/WAREHOUSE_REQUES...
entry.content:
Good day @vicentejarque 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Create a Custom Field in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, KBA 3513578

Your description highlights some customisation requirements that the public cloud due to its clean-core approach does not support.

Let me summarise, the business context /SCWM/WAREHOUSE_REQUEST_HDR only supports UI CDS extensions. However, from my experience, runtime structure extensions are not part of that process. So, yes, it is a restriction to that business context because direct runtime extension of EWM warehouse request is not supported.

To use the field in BAdIs or logic, you may consider using a Custom Business Object or Customs CDS View that is joined with TOR_ID.

 

Best regards

Chris

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 系统中“定义资产类”配置点可以选择“主数据布局”参数，以下主数据布局参数支持“房间”字段：
